channel.title: What are you working on?
channel.description:
[img]https://media3.giphy.com/media/ifxLK48cnyDDi/200_s.gif[/img]
How I feel when I try and post things in any of the RS2 Dev Sections
What are people working on?

item.title: What are you working on?
item.dc:creator: @Tree Tree
item.description:
@Tree wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:40, topic:555053”][quote author=siege engine link=topic=673978.msg4507221#msg4507221 date=1461071804]

Work:

Then at work, I had my app picked up by a government ran company over here in Aus. So that’s causing a lot of stress.

What do you mean by picked up?
[/quote]Well, in Australia, the government is involved in pretty much everything. So a government ran company could mean anything, it means he showed the app and they wanted to use it so they are paying him to customize it for their uses.[/quote]

This ^.

Read full topic

item.title: What are you working on?
item.dc:creator: @Tree Tree
item.description:
@Tree wrote:

At the moment, nothing to do with RS private servers.

Uni:

I’m working on a Unity game to teach logic gates to high school students, a hotel management system and some terrible OpenGL game that makes me want to claw my eyes out.

Work:

Then at work, I had my app picked up by a government ran company over here in Aus. So that’s causing a lot of stress.

item.title: What are you working on?
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

Yes

min = mortonCode(*min(x, y, z, w…))
max = mortonCode(*max(x, y, z, w, …))

search through min -> max

SEARCH, not APPEND.

Read full topic

item.title: What are you working on?
item.dc:creator: @Cres Cres
item.description:
@Cres wrote:

right, and then when you want to retrieve all elements between min_x, max_x, min_y, max_y you convert those into mortonCode(min_x, min_y) and mortonCode(max_x, max_y) and then go through the 1d list?

Read full topic

item.title: What are you working on?
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

Z-Order curve is just a spatial hashing algorithm, it turns N-dimensional coordinates to 1-Dimensional coordinates with a special property where you can effectively do 1-Dimensional range searches on N-dimensional space.

You can use a binary tree to model N-dimensional space and do VERY efficient range searching.

Here’s another example but this one doesn’t play nicely with the fact that Z-Order bits are packed like: xyxyxyxyx which makes it very easy to encode/decode. A majority of spatial hashing algorithms are recursive, which means it takes more computations as the magnitude of your scale increases.

en.wikipedia.org

Hilbert curve

A Hilbert curve (also known as a Hilbert space-filling curve) is a continuous fractal space-filling curve first described by the German mathematician David Hilbert in 1891, as a variant of the space-filling Peano curves discovered by Giuseppe Peano in 1890. Because it is space-filling, its Hausdorff dimension is 2 {\displaystyle 2} (precisely, its image is the unit square, whose dimension is 2 in any definition of dimension; its graph is a compact set h...

Edit: I should be careful as describing it as a 1-Dimensional coordinate, I should just specify the result is a number for all integers which can be used as a 1 dimensional coordinate.

Read full topic

item.title: What are you working on?
item.dc:creator: @Cres Cres
item.description:
@Cres wrote:

idk if I’m doing it correctly with the z-curve thing

gonna use the example implementation of player updating again here lol

so at the start of player updating you just create a quad tree with all the players and that’s it, you do that every single cycle so you don’t have to remove elements in the tree etc

but with the z-curve it’s like, I feel like it takes up more resources and cycles to create the quad using the z-order. is the main purpose of a z-order curve to re-use it or create it every cycle? because I haven’t added removing objects from the tree and wouldn’t know how to do so

Read full topic

item.title: What are you working on?
item.dc:creator: @Cres Cres
item.description:
@Cres wrote:

Neither did I but I got it to work Like yesterday Sini throws this Quad Tree/Z-Order Curve thing at me and I couldn’t figure it out untill I tried it out for myself and got it to work. Also, when working with your own source you really get this sense of accomplishment when a system works the way it should

Read full topic

item.title: What are you working on?
item.dc:creator: @Fabrice_L Fabrice L
item.description:
@Fabrice_L wrote:

[quote=“Cres, post:22, topic:555053”][quote author=Fabrice L link=topic=673978.msg4506262#msg4506262 date=1459098650]
Working on an entire Winterlove rebuild, stripping stuff down and rebuilding it with more efficient code.

Trying to stray away from the awful way PI is done

rune-server.ee

[317] Zlidder ~ Taking Winterlove To New Heights ~

Rune-Server

bitbucket.org

Fabrice_L / Zlidder

Git repository hosted by Bitbucket.


[/quote]

imo you’re much better off just starting from scratch. here’s a list of things you have to re-write anyways:

[ul][li]Player saving[/li]
[li]Player loading[/li]
[li]Player loading/saving should be done on a seperate thread[/li]
[li]Packet handling isn’t that bad in PI, but it could be cleaned up[/li]
[li]The way content is dealt with in the packet handlers[/li]
[li]PI uses blocking IO[/li]
[li]The entire combat system is a bandaid wall[/li]
[li]The player/client classes take up an unnecessary amount of memory due to inefficient code (mostly timers)[/li]
[li]Lack of design means a lot of code that is redundant, look at client.process()[/li][/ul]

Some more stuff I can’t come up with, but yeah. I’ve been working on my own server from scratch using only the information provided by the community and I’ve come a long way. Stuff like java’s ScheduledExecutorService, non blocking IO and a lot more things I couldn’t have ever learned from PI.[/quote]

A whole bunch of that stuff has already been reworked. I’m doing bit by bit, I don’t start from scratch because I don’t really get a hang of networking

Read full topic

item.title: What are you working on?
item.dc:creator: @Cres Cres
item.description:
@Cres wrote:

[quote=“Fabrice L, post:20, topic:555053”]Working on an entire Winterlove rebuild, stripping stuff down and rebuilding it with more efficient code.

Trying to stray away from the awful way PI is done

rune-server.ee

[317] Zlidder ~ Taking Winterlove To New Heights ~

Rune-Server

https://bitbucket.org/Fabrice_L/zlidder[/quote]

imo you’re much better off just starting from scratch. here’s a list of things you have to re-write anyways:

[ul][li]Player saving[/li]
[li]Player loading[/li]
[li]Player loading/saving should be done on a seperate thread[/li]
[li]Packet handling isn’t that bad in PI, but it could be cleaned up[/li]
[li]The way content is dealt with in the packet handlers[/li]
[li]PI uses blocking IO[/li]
[li]The entire combat system is a bandaid wall[/li]
[li]The player/client classes take up an unnecessary amount of memory due to inefficient code (mostly timers)[/li]
[li]Lack of design means a lot of code that is redundant, look at client.process()[/li][/ul]

Some more stuff I can’t come up with, but yeah. I’ve been working on my own server from scratch using only the information provided by the community and I’ve come a long way. Stuff like java’s ScheduledExecutorService, non blocking IO and a lot more things I couldn’t have ever learned from PI.

Read full topic

item.title: What are you working on?
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

Why would you try and emulate Runescript when you could use Lua or another language that already has a parser? Besides the learning experience, I think itd just be pretty inefficient.

Read full topic
